commentaries.bbcode: [b]Wicket![/b] That's goodnight Vienna! Tries to be clever and play the lap sweep, but picks out Kulkarni at short fine leg

message.text: Wicket! That's goodnight Vienna! Tries to be clever and play the lap sweep, but picks out Kulkarni at short fine leg

commentaries.bbcode: Terrific over by Faulkner, and with 45 required from 12, this is going to take a miracle for DD.

message.text: Terrific over by Faulkner, and with 45 required from 12, this is going to take a miracle for DD.

commentaries.bbcode: [b]Wicket![/b] Rajasthan must be relieved they had Steve Smith at long off! Full toss from Kulkarni, he's smashed it down to long off, where Smith does very well to hold on and not go over the rope!

message.text: Wicket! Rajasthan must be relieved they had Steve Smith at long off! Full toss from Kulkarni, he's smashed it down to long off, where Smith does very well to hold on and not go over the rope!

commentaries.bbcode: [b]Rajasthan Royals win by 14 runs[/b]

[b]Match Report: [/b]The Rajasthan Royals returned to winning ways, and regained their position at the top of the Pepsi IPL 2015 standings, after they defeated the Delhi Daredevils by 14 runs. Playing their first match at their adopted home ground   Brabourne Stadium in Mumbai   the Rajasthan Royals rode on half-centuries by Ajinkya Rahane and Karun Nair, and their 113-run partnership, to post 189 runs on the board. When they came out to defend the total, the bowlers restricted the visitors to 175-7. Even though the margin of victory was a small matter of 14 runs, numbers don t really indicate that DD never got their footing in the run-chase. 
 
 Earlier in the evening, after being put in to bat on a track where the ball came on to the bat nicely, Ajinkya Rahane and Karun Nair flourished playing proper cricket strokes. Both batsmen drove fluently, hit plenty of deliveries down the ground, put away short deliveries through midwicket, and once in a while pulled out the sweep and slog-sweep too. The pair came together after Shane Watson and Rahane had stitched together a 52-run opening partnership, made batting look easy and took their team to 165. Karun was the second RR batsman to be dismissed; the Karnataka batsman brought up his half-century off 33 balls, and carried on until he was dismissed in the 19th over of the innings. The 23-year old Karun made till 61 from 38 balls, studded with six boundaries and two sixes. 
 
 Rahane, who reclaimed the Orange Cap, carried his bat through finishing unbeaten on 91. The Mumbai-lad needed 36 balls to get to his half-century, and added 41 runs in the next 18 balls; there were nine fours and three sixes in his 54-ball outing. Rajasthan Royals finished their allotted twenty overs at 189 for 2. 
 
 For the Delhi Daredevils, Zaheer Khan was impressive in his first two overs, before his two other overs cost him 23 runs. Angelo Mathews was the only DD bowler to escape punishment; the Sri Lankan bowled his four overs for 27 runs, picking up the wicket of Watson. Nathan Coulter-Nile was the only other wicket-taker for the visitors. 
 
 When it was their turn to chase, DD kept losing wickets at regular intervals. JP Duminy was the lone warrior for the visitors; the DD skipper scored 56 from 39 balls, aided with three boundaries and three sixes, before he was dismissed in the 18th over. Yuvraj Singh played a couple of crisp strokes before a pull landed in the hands of Stuart Binny patrolling the square-leg boundary. The biggest partnership for DD, who finished their twenty overs at 175-7, was the 41-run stand between Duminy and Angelo Mathews (16). 
 
 James Faulkner celebrated his return to the Rajasthan Royals XI with a brilliant spell of bowling; he picked up the wickets of Duminy and Yuvraj Singh, while conceding only 22 runs in his four overs. Dhawal Kulkarni (2-43), Binny (2-27) and Watson (4-1-25-1) were the other wicket-takers for the hosts.

message.text:
Match Report: The Rajasthan Royals returned to winning ways, and regained their position at the top of the Pepsi IPL 2015 standings, after they defeated the Delhi Daredevils by 14 runs. Playing their first match at their adopted home ground – Brabourne Stadium in Mumbai – the Rajasthan Royals rode on half-centuries by Ajinkya Rahane and Karun Nair, and their 113-run partnership, to post 189 runs on the board. When they came out to defend the total, the bowlers restricted the visitors to 175-7. Even though the margin of victory was a small matter of 14 runs, numbers don’t really indicate that DD never got their footing in the run-chase.

Earlier in the evening, after being put in to bat on a track where the ball came on to the bat nicely, Ajinkya Rahane and Karun Nair flourished playing proper cricket strokes. Both batsmen drove fluently, hit plenty of deliveries down the ground, put away short deliveries through midwicket, and once in a while pulled out the sweep and slog-sweep too. The pair came together after Shane Watson and Rahane had stitched together a 52-run opening partnership, made batting look easy and took their team to 165. Karun was the second RR batsman to be dismissed; the Karnataka batsman brought up his half-century off 33 balls, and carried on until he was dismissed in the 19th over of the innings. The 23-year old Karun made till 61 from 38 balls, studded with six boundaries and two sixes.

Rahane, who reclaimed the Orange Cap, carried his bat through finishing unbeaten on 91. The Mumbai-lad needed 36 balls to get to his half-century, and added 41 runs in the next 18 balls; there were nine fours and three sixes in his 54-ball outing. Rajasthan Royals finished their allotted twenty overs at 189 for 2.

For the Delhi Daredevils, Zaheer Khan was impressive in his first two overs, before his two other overs cost him 23 runs. Angelo Mathews was the only DD bowler to escape punishment; the Sri Lankan bowled his four overs for 27 runs, picking up the wicket of Watson. Nathan Coulter-Nile was the only other wicket-taker for the visitors.

When it was their turn to chase, DD kept losing wickets at regular intervals. JP Duminy was the lone warrior for the visitors; the DD skipper scored 56 from 39 balls, aided with three boundaries and three sixes, before he was dismissed in the 18th over. Yuvraj Singh played a couple of crisp strokes before a pull landed in the hands of Stuart Binny patrolling the square-leg boundary. The biggest partnership for DD, who finished their twenty overs at 175-7, was the 41-run stand between Duminy and Angelo Mathews (16).

James Faulkner celebrated his return to the Rajasthan Royals XI with a brilliant spell of bowling; he picked up the wickets of Duminy and Yuvraj Singh, while conceding only 22 runs in his four overs. Dhawal Kulkarni (2-43), Binny (2-27) and Watson (4-1-25-1) were the other wicket-takers for the hosts.

commentaries.bbcode: [b]Duminy: [/b]"I still think it was the right decision to bowl first. There was quite a bit of carry in the wicket. We brought it back reasonably well. I thought 190 was gettable on this wicket, but we didn't get any partnerships going. We have to win 4 out of 5 to give ourselves a chance of qualifying. I still hope we can qualify. I'm enjoying batting at 3 and enjoying captaincy, but it's about getting wins. We let ourselves down in the field, but it's not all doom and gloom."

message.text: Duminy: "I still think it was the right decision to bowl first. There was quite a bit of carry in the wicket. We brought it back reasonably well. I thought 190 was gettable on this wicket, but we didn't get any partnerships going. We have to win 4 out of 5 to give ourselves a chance of qualifying. I still hope we can qualify. I'm enjoying batting at 3 and enjoying captaincy, but it's about getting wins. We let ourselves down in the field, but it's not all doom and gloom."

commentaries.bbcode: [b]Watson: [/b]"It was an important win. We had lost momentum, but turned it around. Rahane and Nair batted beautifully and the ball swung about nicely on this pitch. I thought there would be a little bit of seam with the new ball. It was nice to get pace and bounce. It was a good cricket wicket. Tonight we did a really good job with the ball. Hopefully, we'll win every game from here on in."

message.text: Watson: "It was an important win. We had lost momentum, but turned it around. Rahane and Nair batted beautifully and the ball swung about nicely on this pitch. I thought there would be a little bit of seam with the new ball. It was nice to get pace and bounce. It was a good cricket wicket. Tonight we did a really good job with the ball. Hopefully, we'll win every game from here on in."

commentaries.bbcode: [b]MoM: [/b]Ajinkya Rahane

tweetjson.text:
All hail Rahane! 
91 off 54 deliveries is amazing.  He gets the Orange Cap again.
Playing wonderfully in this tournament. 
#eit20 #PepsiIPL

commentaries.bbcode: The Rajasthan Royals victory train has left the station once more! The wheels are back in motion, and they'll be delighted that they're edging towards the Playoffs. For DD, they will rue the poor fielding display. Another memorable day of Pepsi IPL cricket has finished, and tomorrow, we've got yet another double header, with the big hitting CSK and RCB going head to head, before KKR and SRH do battle at Eden Gardens. We look forward to seeing you for those.

message.text: The Rajasthan Royals victory train has left the station once more! The wheels are back in motion, and they'll be delighted that they're edging towards the Playoffs. For DD, they will rue the poor fielding display. Another memorable day of Pepsi IPL cricket has finished, and tomorrow, we've got yet another double header, with the big hitting CSK and RCB going head to head, before KKR and SRH do battle at Eden Gardens. We look forward to seeing you for those.
